topic.title: COREOTN Overview

body.p: The COREOTN subsystem processes ODU and OPU overhead, data, and consequential actions across multiple channels concurrently. The COREOTN subsystem has fourtwo bidirectional ODU interfaces (CBR):

li.p: LINEOTN interface (Server interface): Supports ODUCn (n=1-6) and ODU4 rates, up to 600G of Bandwidth
SYSOTN interface (Client interface): Supports ODUCn (n=1-6) and ODU4 rates, up to 600G of Bandwidth, but bandwidth is shared with the MAP interface.

MAPOTN interface (MAP interface): Supports any ODUk clients (ODU0, ODU1, ODU2, ODU1e, ODU2e, ODU3, ODU4, ODUflex (600G)) up to 120 channels. Maximum bandwidth is 600G but is shared with the Client interface.

COPI interface (towards the Fabric I/F): Supports any ODUk clients (ODU0, ODU1, ODU2, ODU1e, ODU2e, ODU1f, ODU2f, ODU3, ODU3e1, ODU3e2 ODU4, ODU4+ ODUflex (500G)) up to 190 channels. Maximum bandwidth is 500G.

body.p: On the Server interface, the COREOTN supports up to one level of ODTUCn muxing and another level of ODTUjk multiplexing using AMP or GMP protocol. The COREOTN also supports one level of HO ODTUj4 and there is an option to add another stage of 100G ODTUjk multiplexing (please refer below to the Modes of Operation, Capabilities, and Limitations). Note that the levels of ODTU multiplexing are optional. In the ODTUCn muxing, the COREOTN supports n= 1-6 with an aggregate bandwidth of 600G. Within a Cn any legal ODUj clients are supported, as per G.709 with maximum of 60 channels in the ODUC6 case. For ODTUjk multiplexing, any legal combination of ODUKs are supported up to ODU4, with an aggregate bandwidth of 600G and 190 channels.
Note : Channels are ODUk’s. Tributary slots are able to be associated with channels/ODUk’s, and unavailable/unallocated/invalid TS/calendar slots do not use up one of the available channel resources.

The COREOTN subsystem complies with the relevant sub-clauses of G.709, G.798, G.806 and Gsup43 data processing from the ODU layers to the OPUk layers. All client layer de-mapping/mapping protocols are handled outside this subsystem except muxing to/from LO ODU clients.

Along with theeach multiplexing stage, there is an ODU layer framing stage, as shown in the block diagram (Stage 1, 2, 3a, 3b, 4, N). There is an RX and TX pair in each stage, the RX framer handles all the TCM, PM and ODU adaptation sink functions and the TX framer handles the counterpart source functions. Within the framers nesting and cascading of TCM’s are supported to realize the various network SNC protocols and fault isolation requirements. The TX and RX framers support ODU layer overhead, but for specific overhead support (like GCC, RES..) an Overhead add/drop port is supported through the OHP block. There is a specific GCC only add/drop port ,which supports HDLC delineated GCC frames. Two Ring Control Ports (RCP) are supported: RI_RCP to connect remote RX or TX framers backward indicator to local RX or TX framers (to perform switching protocols); DI_RCP to advertise chip level defects/PMONs to hardware APS, defect processing or PMON engines.

ODU layer encryption/decryption is supported for ODUk or ODUC level containers for the OPU payload region. There are a total of 6x 100G OTN encryption engines, each is capable of supporting up to 10 ODU channels. Once the 6 encryption engines are connected to a framer stage on startup, they cannot be moved without restarting the device, but the channels can be moved in and out of encryption within a stage.
